occurrences.line_text: But thereat greatly grudged Arthegall,
Whereat the rest gan greatly to enuie:
Yet at her choice they all did greatly muse.
But Blandamour thereat full greatly grudged,
Whence neither greatly hasted to arise,
Did greatly solace his engrieued mind.
And euermore he greatly did desire
But now their forces greatly were decayd,
She gan thereat to fret, and greatly grieue.
Which when he saw, he greatly grew in rage,
For of the meane he greatly did misleeke.
And greatly it desir'd of her to learne,
Her ready to assaile, was greatly queld,
And greatly ioy'd at his so noble hart,
For thy I may not graunt, that ye so greatly prayde.
To make abode that night he greatly was besought.
Too greatly grieue at any his vnlucky case.
Crying for food, did greatly him offend.
That now the same he greatly doth forthinke.
Was greatly growne in loue of that braue pere,
Gan greatly thanke his host and his good wife;
But Calidore he greatly did mistake;
Ne certes mote he greatly blamed be,
And did her greatly like, and did her greatly praize.
And did her greatly like, and did her greatly praize.
Yet greatly did the Beast repine at those
Which to increase his wondrous greatnesse more,
Like belles in greatnesse orderly succeed,
Either fast closed in some hollow greaue,
Yet when she fled into that couert greaue,
Which she accepts, with thankes, and goodly gree,
And gallant shew to be in greatest gree,
But her besought to take it well in gree,
They bring them wines of Greece and Araby,
Not he, whom Greece, the Nourse of all good arts,
And ransackt Greece well tryde, whe[n] they were wroth;
First through the Euxine seas bore all the flowr of Greece.
Which Greece and Asian riuers stained with their blood.
That euer Greece did boast, or knight possesse,
Amongst those famous ympes of Greece, did take
That her all Greece with many a champion bold
Hunting full greedie after saluage blood;
Not all so satisfide, with greedie eye
As when a greedie Wolfe through hunger fell
With greedie pawes, and ouer all did spred
Whiles he himselfe with greedie great desire
Darke, dolefull, drearie, like a greedie graue,
And greedie gulfe does gape, as he would eat
Nor harder was from Cerberus greedie iaw
Nay, nay, thou greedie Tantalus (quoth he)
With greedie malice and importune toyle,
Had in his greedie gulfe deuoured deepe,
Both greedie fiers on other to be wroken.
As when a Vulture greedie of his pray,
Amoret rapt by greedie lust
For ought will from his greedie pleasure spare:
And like a greedie Beare vnto her pray,
Till he himselfe was made their greedie pray,
Vnto her ran with greedie great desyre,
And running all with greedie ioyfulnesse
Long fed his greedie eyes with the faire sight
For he would not his greedie grype forgoe,
Vpon him turned, and with greedie force
The greatest portion of the greedie pray;
With gaping mouth at her ran greedily,
Therewith they gan to hurtlen greedily,
The cruell steele so greedily doth bight
To see their blades so greedily imbrew,
And gan themselues prepare to battell greedily.
In which when as he greedily did looke;
Who all attonce, gaping full greedily,
Or greedily depasturing delight:
But greedily long gaping at the sight,
Vnto his reskew ran, and greedily him sped.
The fearefull boy so greedily pursew,
Like as a Deare, that greedily embayes
The which whyleare she was so greedily
And greedily him griping, his auengement stayd.
Awhile on her they greedily did gaze,
Whom catching greedily for great desire,
With such fell greedines he her assayled,
And eger greedinesse through euery member thrild.
That is the Gulfe of Greedinesse, they say,
But yield her selfe to spoile of greedinesse.
Both challenge it with equall greedinesse:
Full of fell rauin and fierce greedinesse;
But full of fire and greedy hardiment,
With gaping iawes full greedy at him came,
And greedy Auarice by him did ride,
Whose greedy lust did lacke in greatest store,
With greedy force each other doth assayle,
With greedy force he gan the fort assayle,
More greedy they of newes, fast towards him do crosse.
Fast flying from the Paynims greedy pray,
With griping talaunts armd to greedy fight,
But they him spying, both with greedy forse
And boast to swallow her in greedy graue;
Or if to thy great mind, or greedy vew
His greedy flames, and kindled life-deuouring fire.
Threatning with greedy gripe to do him dye
And grieu'd, so long to lacke his greedy pray;
The greedy hunger of reuenging ire,
With greedy pace forth rushing from the forest nye.
But Ã´ the greedy thirst of royall crowne,
Some mouth'd like greedy Oystriges, some fast
Still as the greedy knight nigh to him drew,
Where streame more violent and greedy growes:
And greedy Rosmarines with visages deforme.
And th'amarous sweet spoiles to greedy eyes reuele.
Infixt such secret sting of greedy lust,
The greedy villein from his hoped pray,
With greedy iawes her readie for to teare;
And greedy eares her weake hart from her bore:
With greedy will, and enuious desire,
Her greedy eyes with gazing a long space:
As when two greedy Wolues doe breake by force
Whilest he on him was greedy to be wroke,
His greedy throte, therewith in two distraught,
From greedy hold of that his blouddy feast:
And greedy seas doe in the spoile of life delight.
Did stay a while their greedy bickerment,
And from her griping pounce the greedy prey doth riue.
Her wrathful hand from greedy vengeance to haue stayd.
And gaping greedy wide, did streight deuoure
With greedy rage, and with their faulchins smot;
Succour against her greedy enimy:
But he like hound full greedy of his pray,
And running vnto them with greedy ioyes,
Vppon these warriours, greedy t'vnderstand,
Strongly he stroue out of her greedy gripe
Their greedy vengeaunces, but goary blood,
And greedy to auenge that vile despight,
Pursuing him apace with greedy speede,
And plucke the pray oftimes out of their greedy hould.
He flew vpon him, like a greedy kight
Whylest thus he talkt, the knight with greedy eare
And with delight his greedy fancy fed,
And greedy mouth, wide gaping like hell gate,
With paines farre passing that long wandring Greeke,
With which that wretched Greeke, that life forlore
That many noble Greekes and Troians made to bleed.
From which young Hectors bloud by cruell Greekes was spilt.
Who, after Greekes did Priams realme destroy,
With zelous enuy of Greekes cruell fact,
Of Greekes and Troians, which therein did die;
Of Greekish bloud so oft in Troian plaine;
Letting their steedes to graze vpon the Green:
And their greene leaues trembling with euery blast,
And thinking of those braunches greene to frame
In greene vine leaues he was right fitly clad;
In a greene gowne he clothed was full faire,
She is ybrought vnto a paled greene,
And with greene braunches strowing all the ground,
And with greene boughes decking a gloomy glade,
On top of greene Selinis all alone,
His dwelling is low in a valley greene,
Whose carcases were scattered on the greene,
And tremble like a leafe of Aspin greene,
As fresh as flowres in medow greene do grow,
Then on her head they set a girland greene,
And with greene mosse cou'ring her nakednesse,
The gentlest knight, that euer on greene gras
So fortune wrought, as vnder greene woods syde
Till that they come vnto a forrest greene,
Whom all the people decke with girlands greene,
Of swift Eurotas, or on Cynthus greene,
With nature, did an Arber greene dispred,
The greene shield dyde in dolorous vermell?
With grassie greene of delectable hew,
Mantled with greene, and goodly beautifide
That speare enchaunted was, which layd thee on the greene.
Mantled with greene, it selfe did spredden wyde,
And the greene grasse, that groweth, they shall bren,
To haue besprinckled all the grassy greene;
Planted with mirtle trees and laurels greene,
And with their horned feet the greene grasse wore,
Through the greene gras his long bright burnisht backe declares.
And breaking quite his gyrlond euer greene,
As plaine as at the first, when they were fresh and greene.
His wast was with a wreath of yuie greene
All goodly damzels, deckt with long greene haire,
Fresh Alimeda, deckt with girlond greene;
Burnisht with bloudie rust, whiles on the greene
But scattred all about, and strow'd vpon the greene.
To him he hath, before this Castle greene,
Of Lincolne greene, belayd with siluer lace;
Of all that raungeth in the forrest greene;
Deckt with greene boughes, and flowers gay beseene.
Of few greene turfes an altar soone they fayned,
Yclad in home-made greene that her owne hands had dyde.
He durst not enter into th'open greene,
To the greene wood, to gather strawberies,
Tho sitting downe by them vpon the greene,
The greene-wood long did walke, and wander wide
No tree, that is of count, in greenewood growes,
Vnder the greenewoods side in sorie plight,
Approcht in hast to greet his victorie,
With gentle wordes he can her fairely greet,
The Witch approching gan him fairely greet,
Came running fast to greet his victorie,
As might become a Squire so great persons to greet.
The knight and Vna entring, faire her greet,
It was her guise, all Straungers goodly so to greet.
Goodly she gan faire Cytherea greet,
Old Mnemon. Therefore Sir, I greet you well
In louely wise she gan that Lady greet,
To greet his guerdon vnto euery knight,
And goodly gan to greet his braue emprise,
To greet him the good fortune of his hand:
To greet him first, but askt were where the rest;
Their beuers bright, each other for to greete;
Approching nigh, he neuer stayd to greete,
This happie day I haue to greete you well,
Who, as he could, them goodly well did greete,
He drawing neare, began to greete them faire,
Him goodly greeted in her modest guise,
But to him louted low, and greeted goodly well.
Now when they saw it falne, they eke him greeted all.
Him goodly greetes, and faire does entertaine,
Greeting his graue: his grudging ghost did striue
Greeting him goodly with new victorie,
Who well them greeting, humbly did requight,
Her greeting sends in these sad lines addrest,
The Championesse them greeting, as she could,
Who with right humble thankes him goodly greeting,
The villaine, wroth for greeting him so sore,
And first him greeting, thus vnto him spake;
Who first vs greets, and after faire areedes
And greeu'd, to thinke how foe did him destroy,
Greeu'd with remembrance of his wicked wayes,
Though greeued ghost for vengeance deepe do grone:
For that same mayd, how euer it him greeues,
And some of Tygres, that did seeme to gren,
And gently grenning, shew a semblance glad
That by his grenning laughter mote farre off be rad.
That for my sake vnknowne such griefe vnto you grew.
Where grew two goodly trees, that faire did spred
By which he grew to grieuous malady;
Which by misdiet daily greater grew:
She greatly grew amazed at the sight,
Thereby so fearelesse, and so fell he grew,
For seuen great heads out of his body grew,
Which greater grew, the more she did contend,
But all still shronke, and still he greater grew:
Before their rage grew to so great vnrest,
The faithfull knight now grew in litle space,
At their first presence grew agrieued sore,
Or his baptized hands now greater grew;
There grew a goodly tree him faire beside,
Another like faire tree eke grew thereby,
Grew all afore, and loosely hong vnrold,
There mournfull Cypresse grew in greatest store,
On earth like neuer grew, ne liuing wight
Here eke that famous golden Apple grew,
To reach the fruit, which grew vpon the brincke:
Had lost, he by him spide, right glad he grew,
And Gorbogud, till farre in yeares he grew:
Whereof great trouble in the kingdome grew,
Grew great, and got large portions of land,
Of these a mightie people shortly grew,
And shortly grew to so great quantitie,
That nigh he breathlesse grew, yet nought dismaid,
Now making girlonds of each flowre that grew,
Which in that cloth was wrought, as if it liuely grew.
And yet in armes Noctante greater grew:
Eftsoones she grew to great impatience
When the two fearefull women saw, they grew
Grew pensiue through that amorous discourse,
For whom he wondrous pensiue grew in mind,
But when she better him beheld, she grew
And all the sweetest flowres, that in the forrest grew.
Till thither they returne, where first they grew:
And all about grew euery sort of flowre,
In which when she to perfect ripenesse grew,
She grew familiare in that desert place.
And shortly grew into outrageous fire;
And of her safetie greatly grew afrayd;
Greatly he grew enrag'd, and furiously
With thought whereof, exceeding mad he grew,
That of the antique Troian stocke, there grew
Exceeding wroth therewith the virgin grew,
Till that to ripenesse of mans state they grew:
Vpon which ground this same great battell grew,
But Cambell still more strong and greater grew,
By which few crooked sallowes grew in ranke:
Whereby the passion grew more fierce and faine,
Then faire grew foule, and foule grew faire in sight,
Then faire grew foule, and foule grew faire in sight,
Till she had duld the sting, which in her tongs end grew.
But there was planted, or grew naturall:
And she her selfe likewise diuinely grew;
His cheeke bones raw, and eie-pits hollow grew,
And all things freely grew out of the ground:
Began to spring which shortly grew full great,
And towards th'end, grew greater in his might,
Which when he saw, he greatly grew in rage,
Of that sad stroke, that halfe enrag'd she grew,
So much the greater still her anguish grew,
In minde he grew, for feare least by that art
That of his game she soone enwombed grew,
With that all mad and furious he grew,
She with the sting, which in her vile tongue grew,
Till it to ripenesse grew, and forth to honour burst.
Till he to perfect ripenesse grew, and then
He greater grew, and gan to driue at him more hard.
But still his passion grew more violent and strong.
Full glad and ioyous then young Tristram grew,
With that the wyld man more enraged grew,
And for exceeding griefe which inly grew,
Beheld, eftsoones he all enraged grew,
But she thereof grew proud and insolent,
He lost himselfe, and like one halfe entraunced grew.
Where shortly they in great acquaintance grew,
Which when her father vnderstood, he grew
The litle purple rose, which thereon grew,
Forth budded, and in greater number grew.
And to her weapon ran, in minde to gride
Such was the wound that Scudamour did gride;
Harts grief, and bitter gall away to chace,
His gall did grate for griefe and high disdaine,
That for my sake vnknowne such griefe vnto you grew.
Will was his guide, and griefe led him astray.
He oft finds med'cine, who his griefe imparts;
And fretting griefe the enemy of life;
Whom great griefe made forget the raines to hold
Cause of my new griefe, cause of my new ioy,
For sorrowes past; their griefe is with them gone:
Him to beguile of griefe and agony:
Which in false griefe hyding his harmefull guile,
For griefe whereof the lad n'ould after ioy,
The further processe of her hidden griefe;
Then rip vp griefe, where it may not auaile,
Well may I weene, your griefe is wondrous great;
For wondrous great griefe groneth in my spright,
O but (quoth she) great griefe will not be tould,
But griefe (quoth she) does greater grow displaid,
You to inquere the secrets of my griefe,
This is my cause of griefe, more great, then may be told.
Such percing griefe her stubborne hart did wound,
And with great griefe were often heard to grone,
Had no delight to treaten of his griefe;
Embost with bale, and bitter byting griefe,
Could hardly him intreat, to tell his griefe:
Then full of griefe and anguish vehement,
The griefe thereof him wondrous sore diseasd,
For griefe thereof, and diuelish despight,
For thy appease your griefe and heauie plight,
And now exceeding griefe him ouercame,
Let one word fall that may your griefe vnfold,
He oft finds present helpe, who does his griefe impart.
Or die with you in sorrow, and partake your griefe.
From teares abstaine, for griefe his hart did grate,
Nor fry in hartlesse griefe and dolefull teene.
To fret for anger, or for griefe to mone?
Ah God, what horrour and tormenting griefe
Thus heaping crime on crime, and griefe on griefe,
Thus heaping crime on crime, and griefe on griefe,
As griefe and furie vnto me did bring;
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
Wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue do thus expell:
Griefe is a flood, and loue a monster fell;
So shall wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue dye and decay.
Knotted in bloud and dust, for griefe of mind,
But griefe and wrath, that be her enemies,
Which when as Archimago heard, his griefe
Leauing behind them griefe and heauinesse.
Which when his brother saw, fraught with great griefe
And inward griefe, he fiercely gan approch,
All pleasaunce was to them griefe and annoy:
A gyaunt babe, her selfe for griefe did kill;
Much greater griefe and shamefuller regret
With sighes, and sobs, and plaints, & piteous griefe,
And by long triall of the inward griefe,
Like an huge Aetn' of deepe engulfed griefe,
Of my deare foster child, to ease thy griefe,
But rather doth my helpelesse griefe augment.
Old Glauce cast, to cure this Ladies griefe:
And sayd, Sith then thou knowest all our griefe,
Both for his griefe, and for her peoples sake,
Huge sea of sorrow, and tempestuous griefe,
She shut vp all her plaint in priuy griefe;
The mist of griefe dissolu'd, did into vengeance powre.
Tho full of bitter griefe and pensiue thought,
Exceeding griefe that wound in him empight,
Would hardly find to aggrauate her griefe;
His former griefe with furie fresh reuiued,
Die had she rather in tormenting griefe,
His inward griefe, by meanes to him well knowne,
Into huge waues of griefe and gealosye
Long thus he chawd the cud of inward griefe,
Ne griefe might not his loue to him restore,
And tell thy griefe, if any hidden lye;
Ne word he had to speake, his griefe to tell,
Griefe, and despight, and gealosie, and scorne
Where he through priuy griefe, and horrour vaine,
Fit medcine to his griefe, and spake thus courtesly.
Ah gentle knight, whose deepe conceiued griefe
For griefe whereof, ye mote haue liuely seene
Next him went Griefe, and Fury matcht yfere;
Griefe all in sable sorrowfully clad,
Hath no lesse griefe endured for your gentle sake.
And all the way with wondrous griefe of mynd,
He was full wo, and gan his former griefe renew.
Was thrild with inward griefe, as when in chace
With double life, and griefe, which when he felt,
So much the more her griefe, the more her toyle:
Yet neither toyle nor griefe she once did spare,
What equall torment to the griefe of mind,
Streight into griefe, that her deare hart nigh swelt,
That seekes to know anothers griefe in vaine,
Yet found no ease of griefe, nor hope of grace,
As one with griefe and anguishe ouercum,
The great tormenting griefe, that for her sake
But if through inward griefe or wilfull scorne
And wound the soule it selfe with griefe vnkind:
But most she touched was with griefe entire,
Sith loue was first the ground of all her griefe,
Yet hoping griefe may lessen being told,
And when my weary ghost with griefe outworne,
That euen for griefe of minde he oft did grone,
To see an helpelesse euill, double griefe doth lend.
Or griefe vnknowne, which he could not discerne:
Thinking to haue her griefe by death bereaued.
But Radigund full of heart-gnawing griefe,
So she departed, full of griefe and sdaine,
And then, her griefe with errour to beguyle,
With sodaine stounds of wrath and griefe attone:
Chawing the cud of griefe and inward paine,
With inward griefe and malice did against them swell.
For his departure, her new cause of griefe;
Gan weepe and wayle, as if great griefe had her affected.
And lastly Griefe did plead, and many teares forth powre.
But by her tempred without griefe or gall,
Ye dolefull Dame, let not your griefe empeach
Therefore faire Lady lay aside this griefe,
Temper his griefe, and turned it to cheare,
Each others griefe with zeale affectionate,
Sith then ye needs will know the griefe I hoord,
Lo this my cause of griefe to you appeares;
With tender ruth for her vnworthy griefe:
And for exceeding griefe which inly grew,
Had giuen them, whose griefe through suffraunce sore increast.
Words sharpely wound, but greatest griefe of scorning growes.
But after griefe awhile had had his course,
But Calidore recomforting his griefe,
But chiefly Calidore, whom griefe had most possest.
This griefes deepe wound I would to thee disclose,
That piteously complaind her carefull grieffe,
Which when she sees with ghastly griefful eies,
But double griefs afflict concealing harts,
And griefull pittie priuately bemone.
His griesie lockes, long growen, and vnbound,
He bad awake blacke Plutoes griesly Dame,
Of griesly Pluto she the daughter was,
Where griesly Night, with visage deadly sad,
And her darke griesly looke them much dismay;
Or other griesly thing, that him agast.
Wide gaped, like the griesly mouth of hell,
A cruell knife, that made a griesly wound,
The slouthfull waue of that great griesly lake;
Of griesly hew, and fowle ill fauour'd sight;
That streight did lead to Plutoes griesly raine:
Through griesly shadowes by a beaten path,
With their rude hands and griesly graplement,
They passing by, that griesly mouth did see,
The griesly Wasserman, that makes his game
And sore annoyed, groping in that griesly night.
Full griesly seem'd: therein they long did ryde,
Lo where a griesly Foster forth did rush,
And all the griesly Monsters of the See
They softly gan to search his griesly wound:
And griesly shadowes couered heauen bright,
The state of life, out of the griesly shade.
And stinking Sulphure, that with griesly hate
Straunge horrour, to deforme his griesly shade;
And in their flesh a griesly passage rend,
By griesly Lachesis was spun with paine,
Vnto her rest in Plutoes griesly land,
And therein made a very griesly wound,
Full blacke and griesly did his face appeare,
She looking backe, espies that griesly wight
He let to grow and griesly to concrew,
Did waite about it, gaping griesly all begor'd.
Vnto the bone, and made a griesly wound,
And made a griesly wound in his enriuen side.
Then brought he forth, with griesly grim aspect,
To wander in the griesly shades of night.
And grinning griesly, did against him weld
Two griesly creatures; and, to that their faces
Hauing both sides through grypt with griesly wound.
Gnashing his grinded teeth with griesly looke,
And griesly wounds that him appalled sore.
Of griesly theeues, she thought her self in hell,
Who in the horror of the griesly night,
Appearing like the mouth of Orcus griesly grim.
To griesly Pluto, what on earth was donne,
Yeeld such a sore, that doth her grieuance hide,
In plainer wise to tell her grieuaunce she begonne.
Through grieuaunce of his late receiued wound,
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
